The GLOF-II project was launched in 2017, highlighting a long-standing government effort to combat climate risks through technological early warning systems.
The World Bank’s 2023 climate report on Pakistan’s temperature rise underscores the country’s rapid warming trend, which is accelerating glacial melt and climate disasters.

The article’s current context (2025) emphasizes the continued urgency of climate adaptation, especially as warming trends persist and communities rely on traditional knowledge.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge systems, such as observing animal behavior, cloud formations, and sound patterns, are being used by local communities in Gilgit-Baltistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

Despite government investment in early warning systems (EWS), including the $37 million GLOF-II project, trust among local populations is low due to system failures, lack of maintenance, and poor community engagement.

A shepherd named Wasiyat Khan and others in the Roshan and Skardu valleys have saved lives through timely human-initiated alerts using traditional signals like gunfire, which have proven more effective than malfunctioning EWS technology.
Pakistan is among the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations, with temperatures rising twice as fast as the global average since the 1950s, exacerbating glacier melt and flood risks.

The lack of trust in official systems has led to community-led actions becoming the primary method of early warning, underscoring the need for culturally inclusive and community-trusted climate resilience strategies.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan, especially in Gilgit-Baltistan, communities are increasingly relying on Indigenous knowledge—such as observing animal behavior, cloud formations, and using gunfire or fire signals—to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), despite government efforts to deploy early warning systems (EWS). These systems, including the $37 million GLOF-II project, have failed to gain trust due to technical malfunctions, lack of maintenance, and poor community engagement. Real-life accounts from shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain demonstrate that human-based early warnings, passed down through generations, have saved lives more effectively than malfunctioning technology. Pakistan’s rising temperatures, with a 1.3°C increase since the 1950s, have intensified glacial melt and flood risks. The government’s lack of transparency and accountability in EWS implementation has led to widespread public skepticism, with communities turning to traditional practices as a more reliable form of climate resilience.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
